https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Influenza_pandemic lists six (1889-1890, 1918-1920, 1957-1958, 1968-1969, 1977-1978,
& 2009-2010) in about 110 years, with interregna of 28, 37, 10, 8, & 31 years (mean = 28 years).  Alternatively,   13 in 
about 110 years (.11 of years) were marked as pandemic.  It is late November 2018, leaving .125 years before 2019.
.11*.125=0.01375, so maybe about 1 1/3% chance and the entry box only takes integers, so 1.

In 2009, during the H1N1 pandemic, it took the WHO 3 months between the first reported case (25 March) before declaring a Phase 6 pandemic (11 June 2009). Even assuming reporting, documentation, and alert systems have improved both sub-nationally and nationally within countries and transnationally from countries to international health organisations like WHO, a certain number of cases which will develop over time will be part of the classification of a pandemic. Slightly higher numbers of reported cases of influenza have been reported in SE Asia. However, there are only 2 calendar months left of the year, which even with improved reporting, alert systems etc., which means it is unlikely that there is enough time for enough reported influence cases to be classified as a pandemic.

October 25th 2019
Outside view:
 The fourth lesson is to continue to mine the five pandemics we have data from—1889  1918, 1957, 1968, and 2009—for insights.
https://naturemicrobiologycommunity.nature.com/users/79120-john-barry/posts/29254-the-1918-influenza-pandemic-in-its-time-will-we-learn-for-the-future  So crude outside view gives :  5 / (2017 - 1889) = 0.0390625 change of pandemic per year Since there is only 2/12 months  of the 2018 left we have :  2/12 * 0.0390625 = 0.006510417 change of pandemic for this year Inside view: 
 CDC:
 For the week ending October 13 (week 41), the proportion of people seeing their health care provider for influenza-like illness (ILI) was 1.4% and is below the national baseline of 2.2%. 
According to this week’s FluView report, seasonal influenza activity is low overall across the United States. 
New York City, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and 49 states experienced minimal ILI activity.

 WHO:
In the temperate zones of the southern hemisphere, influenza activity appeared to decrease overall though influenza percent positivity remained elevated in Southern Africa. In Australia and New Zealand, influenza activity remained at low levels and even below seasonal threshold during the entire season. Increased influenza detections were reported in some countries of Southern and South-East Asia. In the temperate zone of the northern hemisphere influenza activity remained at inter-seasonal levels. To summarize outside view  the flu levels are lower than normal. One metric for the us is "influenza-like illness (ILI) was 1.4% and is below the national baseline of 2.2%. " so 1.4 / 2.2. = 0.63 % of the usual value . WHO also report below normal value at some place or on par in Asia. So let's take 0.63% as a good approximation of the overall probability for the world Summary: 
0.006510417 * 63% = 0.004143 = 0.4143% of change of a pandemic before 2019.
So the only question remaining question is if we should round up or down. I'll round down since it is below 0.5%
Pandemic possibility is negligible before 2019. There is not enough time. If we do get a pandemic it will be something far worse than influenza and have a crazy propagation rate.

Only 7.7 percent of the US is seeking treatment for an illness are being treated for the flu. The last one was in 2009 and is expected to happen every 24 years or so. 80,000 people died from flu-related deaths last year, and it's important to examine data between flu deaths and flu-related deaths. It's the 7th leading cause of death in the US and can be prevented with the vaccine. I don't believe it will be declared a pandemic in the two months before 2019.

I believe there is a 0% chance of an influenza pandemic occurring before 2019. For starters, there are only about two months left in 2018 and based on weekly reports by the CDC "Influenza activity in the United States remains low." As of now, there has only been one pediatric death that was associated with influenza.  Based off of this, it can be assumed that influenza activity will stay low for the next few weeks at least.  Moreover, at the very beginning of 2018, the CDC reported widespread virus activity for the first time in 13 years. Even with these record breaking numbers WHO and the CDC did not suggest a pandemic. This shows that even with higher rates of influenza, it is unlikely there will be a pandemic. Lastly, since 1889, there have only been five pandemics total, with the shortest gap between outbreaks being 11 years and the overall average being one outbreak every 25 years. With that being said, it is very unlikely we will see an outbreak, especially due to the very low levels of influenza at the moment, and we are just hitting the 9 year mark between pandemics, making it numerically unlikely as well.  https://naturemicrobiologycommunity.nature.com/users/79120-john-barry/posts/29254-the-1918-influenza-pandemic-in-its-time-will-we-learn-for-the-future
http://time.com/5108077/2018-flu-map/
https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/index.htm

5 influenza pandemics to date.  —1889  1918, 1957, 1968, and 2009 https://naturemicrobiologycommunity.nature.com/users/79120-john-barry/posts/29254-the-1918-influenza-pandemic-in-its-time-will-we-learn-for-the-future 120 years total time span, suggests a pandemic is due approximately every 24 years. The shortest gap on record is between 1957 and 1968. That suggests the earliest possible data is 2020. But historical data is almost irrelevant to forecasting the flue, much more convincing would be a model with accurate data on influenza viruses in birds, pigs and humans. Such data and models doesn't exist. The article outlines how questionable and low quality the data and algorithms are, and their poor performance to date. What to know before forecasting the flu
https://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005964

There are usually only 3 pandemics a century and occur when a new strain is transferred from an animal to a human. The most recent pandemic was in 2009 with H1N1. In the year H1N1 was introduced, an estimated 41% of U.S. citizens received flu shots compared to over 45% in 2015 and over 46% in 2016. This is a lower rate than many other nations. The CDC has also increased public awareness of proper swine handling in order to decrease initial infection to new flu viruses. They also monitor influenza year round and quickly research any novel strains in order to mitigate the effects and prevent spread. A mild winter is followed by a severe flu season 72% of the time (https://www.concentra.com/resource-center/articles/the-impact-of-climate-change-on-flu/). As last winter was relatively mild, I do not yet lower my prediction as the 2018-2019 season is about to begin.

Following @OldWiseSage777 on the basis of data and analysis presented at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/768869
Thank you.

There where 4 influenza pandemics over the last 100 years. In 1918 the spanish, in 1957 the asian and in 1968 the hong kong flu. Plus the 2009 flu pandemic.  This suggests a rough base rate of about 4% per year. We still have 4 months in the year. Which suggests 1.33%. However, a pandemic needs time to grow. For instance SARS started in november and it took until march before the WHO issued a warning. About 5 months. So given the time a disease needs to grow, there's only 1 month left for it to start. 1/12*4% = 0.33%  I round down to 0%

https://www.cdc.gov/flu/pandemic-resources/1918-commemoration/pandemic-flu-fighter-dan-jernigan.htm Medical and technological advances made in the fight against influenza since 1918 are numerous. “First of all, we have identified that it was an influenza virus that caused the pandemic in 1918. At the time, they didn’t know that,” says Dr. Jernigan. In addition to new information about and understanding of influenza viruses themselves, we also have new medical advancements in how we treat influenza and influenza-related complications. “We have antiviral drugs that can target the virus itself. We have ventilators and intensive care units. We have vaccines. We have so much more capability now,” adds Dr. Jernigan. While significant advancement has been made in flu prevention, other modern developments may contribute to the impact of a pandemic today. The world is more crowded and the worlds of humans and animals continue to converge, both factors that promote the emergence of novel influenza viruses, Dr. Jernigan says. Because most influenza viruses that cause pandemics start in the animal population, improving avian and swine influenza surveillance is very important. Everyday work in the Influenza Division centers around the study of seasonal influenza and novel influenza viruses that have pandemic potential, notes Dr. Jernigan. “Viruses are constantly changing, so that means we have to constantly monitor them. They have minor little changes that can occur throughout the year and so you have to look at them every month, even every week.”  Because influenza viruses are constantly changing and the risk of pandemic influenza is imminent we must continue to expand our understanding of influenza viruses. . . . “A big challenge is vaccine — our flu vaccines take a long time to make and they have to be made to target specific viruses.  Immunity from vaccination wanes over time so people need to be revaccinated annually,” Dr. Jernigan says. “We need flu vaccines that can be made more quickly, that offer longer lasting protection, and that protect against many different flu viruses. What would be wonderful would be to develop a universal vaccine that would protect against all flu viruses. But in the interim, we can make better vaccines.” The systems that we use for seasonal influenza; virus surveillance, vaccine manufacturing, and vaccine development, are the foundation of our response to the next flu pandemic.  They all need to continue improving so if we have another bad pandemic like the one in 1918, we will be much more prepared and better protected.”
~~~~~~~

Flu season in decline in northern hemisphere.  Chance of pandemic in 2018 seems reduced.
Base rate is extremely low as a pandemic requires a new strain, moving from the animal world to humans. From the wiki flu season page:
"In the United States, the flu season is considered October through May.[9] It usually peaks in February.[10] In Australia, the flu season is considered May to October. It usually peaks in August.[11]
Flu seasons also exist in the tropics and subtropics, but are usually less sharply defined. In Hong Kong, which has a humid subtropical climate, the flu season runs from December to March, in the winter and early spring.[12][13]"

Pandemics, as many low probability events, are notoriously hard to predict. Their base rate over the past century has been once every 20 to 25 years. This puts the yearly base probability rate at 4-5 %. Neither the CDC or the WHO have ramped up their surveillance of a particular strain yet. The definition of pandemics involves strains not currently circulating in the population. I tried getting more from the CDC IRAT scores, but found no sensible way to turn them into probability estimates. The CDC itself only uses them to give relative risk factors (low, medium, high). In the end, these might only influence the base rate by a couple of percentage points. I'll stick to standard probability estimates for now, and count them down on a monthly basis, unless either agency starts communicating about an emergent pre pandemic phase. With the highest of the two base rates (5%), and the time remaining until the question closes (10 months), that gives an estimate of 4%.

We'll see what happens next year though.

There is a history of influenza pandemics the CDC has historically declared, including the avian flu. This year's influenza epidemic in the US has demonstrated that the vaccine can prove inadequate. The amount of international travel is significant enough to create the possibility of a flu virus spreading globally via airplane cabins, which are ripe opportunities for transmittal;  there is one additional flu season ahead prior to 2019; the movement of Syrian refugees into Europe and the inadequacy of their preventive health care creates a basis for new concerns. Research is targeting new vaccines and more effectively to inoculate against the flu given this year's experience in the US.

Useful links:
What defines an "influenza pandemic"?
http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/89/7/11-086173/en/ (which compares the WHO and CDC definitions)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Influenza_pandemic (stages of pandemic influenza phases)
http://www.upmc-cbn.org/report_archive/2009/2009-SW-H1N1-Issue-Briefs/2009-06-11-A_Closer_Look_at_WHO_Pandemic_Declaration.html (Process of stepping though the phases).
https://www.cdc.gov/flu/pandemic-resources/monitoring/irat-virus-summaries.htm (Current threat assessments of the various FluA subtypes being monitored.) Also of importance, a discussion with an Infectious Diseases physician friend of mine, especially about the 2009 pandemic. In short, the risk of a pandemic in the next 12 months is no greater than it has been in the last few years (ie. no particularly ominous clouds on the horizon, just the ongoing threat assessments).  However, when an influenza pandemic eventually occurs, it is likely to come out of nowhere, going from Phase 3 (a few extra case reports) to Phase 5 (an impending phase 6 pandemic) within a few weeks.  From that point of view, we probably can't do much better than using baseline risk to predict. And with 5 pandemics in the last 100 years, and 4 in the last 60 years, that baseline risk is in the realm of about 5-7% annually, or about 0.5% per month.  Is there any reason to vary widely from that baseline? Increased travel in modern times?
A pandemic is more likely to wash over the world more quickly, but I don't think that makes a pandemic any more likely.  It just means that there will be near-simultaneous outbreaks everywhere, rather than the slow-motion waves of cases that were seen over 2-3 years with the 1918-1920 Spanish Flu. Better surveillance?
Early adaptation of public health measures might decrease (slightly) transmission in prepared populations, and might result in resource allocation that saves lives.  I can't see it making much of a difference preventing a pandemic occurring though.  (Speaking from my own experience as a primacy care physician here.)  Similarly, we might be in a better position to develop vaccines and treatments more promptly, but once again, this won't prevent the pandemic occurring. Increased population?
I think increased pig and chicken populations to act as incubators for new strains of influenza are balanced out by virological monitoring of those populations, and willingness in most (but not all) parts of the world to intervene decisively as something appears to be brewing.   So overall, start at the baseline risk (6.5% given 13 months remaining), and see how things go from there ...
Little time remaining this year and no evidence so far of marked increase in flu

https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2017/10/h7n9-flu-pandemic/543318/
Every year since, there’s been a new epidemic, and the current one is the worst. H7N9 has evolved, acquiring mutations that allow other flu strains to reproduce more effectively in both birds and mammals. It has started killing birds. In one year, H7N9’s highly pathogenic (“high-path”) strains have caused as many human infections as the previous four epidemics put together. As of September 20, there have been 1,589 laboratory-confirmed cases, and 39 percent of those people have died. “It was a matter of time,” says the flu expert Yoshihiro Kawaoka, from the University of Wisconsin-Madison. “It wasn’t surprising to see this change.”
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Very hard to predict other than it will probably happen at some point in future. The global conflict/disaster of Jul 1914 - Nov 1918 could accelerate the evolution of a pandemic virus. This estimate is based on either the WHO or CDC declaring an H7N9 or H7N9-derived avian influenza virus pandemic prior to 2019. Reference classes:
The WHO time-line and criteria of pandemic declaration for the 2009 H1N1 influenza virus
The previous 1918, 1957, 1968, and 2009 influenza pandemics.
SARS, MERS, and Zika virus outbreaks.
H5N1 avian influenza.
Current seasonal influenza viruses. Assumptions:
Basic reproduction number (R0) of a pandemic H7N9 would be ~1.7
Confirmed poultry-to-human cases in China will follow the increasing trend of previous waves and the similar duration. I estimate that there will be approximately 700 poultry-to-human cases (650-950) or lower, if the poultry vaccination program in China is successful, for the remainder of 2017 and 2018.
The high case fatality rate of H7N9 in humans is unlikely to substantially curtail the R0 enough to prevent a pandemic due to peak viral shedding preceding the onset of symptoms or the case fatality rate of the H7N9-derived pandemic will decrease upon adaptation to facilitate spread.
The H7 viral protein will have a similar preference for the alpha 2-3 sialic acid receptors over the alpha 2-6 sialic acid receptors as other avian influenza viruses. Other considerations going into this estimate include:
The close proximity of the previous cases in the Western Pacific WHO region to the Europe and SE Asia WHO regions.
The absence of an obvious mixing vessel for reassortment.
Confirmed case of human-to-human transmission of the virus.
The diversification of the H7N9 virus since 2013.
The length of the influenza season in the region.
The score from the Centers for Disease Control's Influenza Risk Assessment Tool. References:
Previous influenza pandemics

There have been 4 pandemics declared by the CDC in the past century, therefore the chance of one occurring within the next year or so is very low. Additionally, the WHO is re-evaluating their definition of a pandemic after the last one in 2009 (H1N1) did not turn out to be as severe as predicted. However, changes in the global climate may facilitate increased spread of viruses, which could increase the possibility of another pandemic.

Chances seem slim that it will reach pandemic levels in less than a year and a half, though based on reports, the possibility seems real enough to put the chances just under 10%. As the NYT article linked in question states, the avian flu in China gets more aggressive every year, though the fatality rate is far from catastrophic. But, if certain events/unrest transpire in that part of the world, it feels conceivable that treating a flu outbreak could become a bigger problem if there are more serious issues/obstacles at the forefront.
Despite larger numbers getting the flu shot, many are still coming down with the flu. The viruses are adapting to our defenses. It is only a matter of time.

Updates based on news out of India that the current vaccine does not address their recent flu cases: http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chandigarh/docs-worry-over-new-strain-of-swine-flu/articleshow/59946034.cms

Let's not get dramatic. "Pandemic" does not mean "oh god oh god we're all going to die"; it is not an apocalyptic scenario. Pandemic simply means that a serious case of flu will spread to multiple regions across the globe, enough to warrant media attention and probably claim a small number of lives. That's why my forecasts are higher. I think that, at any time, we exist with a solid 30 percent chance of a highly-communicable infection like flu popping up, doing some damage, getting headlines and then fading out. I don't think going higher than 30-35 percent is warranted without serious data analytics to back up such claims, but 2-10 percent, in my opinion, is too low and does not account for the relative elasticity of the term "pandemic".
It's a hundred years since last time, a nice round number - maybe these could be cyclic?

Base value is based on recurrence trends of past pandemics from 1889-2010 (approx. every 24 years), with 1 year and 5 months remaining until 2019 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Influenza_pandemic#Nature_of_a_flu_pandemic). I modified this slightly due to a rise in influenza vaccine distribution, particularly in developing countries from 2004-2013 (http://eswi.org/knowledge-center/wp-content/uploads/sites/11/2014/07/global-influenza-vaccine-distribution-Vaccine-2015.pdf).
Based on past history of possible epidemics that did not come to pass due to effective vaccinations.

Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Current trend seems to be decreasing cases for 2017 (http://www.who.int/csr/don/28-june-2017-ah7n9-china/en/), with only handfuls of recent reporting in China and France (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-birdflu-france-idUSKBN19L2PF). The most telling data point is the 1533 cases since 2013, or just over 300/yr. Additionally, early detection within the poultry communities and countermeasures taken (culling the birds) seems to help mitigate potential outbreaks (http://www.readingeagle.com/berks-country/article/opinion-proactive-approach-stems-spread-of-avian-flu).

Pandemics are uncommon. However, it seems that the effectiveness of flu immunization might decrease with repeated immunizations (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21022).  During the H1N1 pandemic in 2009 Dr. Dr. Danuta Skowronski from UBC found that people who were immunized had almost twice the risk of getting H1N1.  The findings have been reported in academic journals and by the Canadian Broadcasting Company.   http://www.cbc.ca/news/health/flu-vaccine-paradox-adds-to-public-health-debate-1.2912790  Many people have been immunized repeatedly. There is not yet a technology to assure that the flu immunizations of a particular year will necessarily provide protection against the current years flu.   There are economic incentives to detect a flu epidemic and promote further vaccines. Industry and government are try to gather support to develop and implement a single shot vaccine. The projection is based on the idea that overall flu resistance will decline in people who have had repeated flu immunizations, and the incentives to detect an epidemic. I do not know of any evidence suggesting that the decreased resistance with increased immunizations applies to other vaccines.  Although I accept that repeated flu vaccines might be associated with increased risk, it is important to know that the evidence for this conclusion is not strong.

Pandemics are 'chaotic systems': they behave non-linear (exponential growth of cases) and dynamic (the output of one stage influences its future pathway)(cf. Silver, 2013, The Signal and the Noise, Chapter 7, on predictability of flu pandemics)
- see the comment by @kinghasa4u here: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/526538 How often do influenza pandemics occur?
- Roughly around 25 to 20 years (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Influenza_pandemic#Influenza_pandemics) 
	○ odds for one season are: 0,05
	○ odds for two seasons at least once: 0,05*0,95 + 0,95*0,05 + 0,05*0,05 = 0,0975 How often does the CDC declare an influenza pandemic?
- unknown: never? How often does the WHO declare an influenza pandemic?
- only once: 2009 Are there factors which may account for more frequent influenza pandemics in the future than in the past?
- antibiotic resistance?
- mass animal husbandry?
- global travel? Are there reasons to assume that CDC or WHO will be careful in declaring an influenza pandemic?
- One should distinguish between the case as such, an influenza pandemic, and the declaration of the pandemic by an organization like WHO or CDC - as one should distinguish the case of a famine in Nigeria and its declaration by the UN FAO (cf.: https://www.gjopen.com/questions/464-will-the-un-declare-a-famine-in-any-part-of-nigeria-in-2017). Labeling an event is political as it helps to answer the Lasswell-question: Who gets what, when, how?
- 2009 declaration of influenza pandemic was seen as a failure, and scientific community is going to discuss when pandemics should be declared (see here: http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/89/7/11-086173/en/, cf. Silver, 2013, The Signal and the Noise, Chapter 7)… but Silver also discusses self-canceling effects of predicting pandemics - which would, paradoxically, indicate success of declaring pandemics. In essence, it seems not possible to have an 'inside view' with a gain of knowledge. That is the lesson of Nate Silvers' Chapter on predicting pandemics. Complex models do not help: we lack both, data and understanding. So we are forced to rely on the base rates. I therefore start with 9 percent.

For a disease to reach pandemic stage, there would have to be either delay in recognition or increased virulence/transmission of the new virus. The CDC regularly monitors potential hotspots for new influenza strains. The last flu pandemic recognized by the CDC was in 2009, the Swine Flu. The CDC evaluates the various flu strains and prioritizes research on how to treat/vaccinate against them based on their potential risk of transmission & impact. It does not public pandemic potentials for each strain. There is greater international cooperation in preventing another flu pandemic, for instance via the WHO. Individual countries have developed quick responses, particularly in Asia, which may include widespread quarantine and even slaughter of livestock. We will likely continue to have local epidemics, but the risk of a worldwide pandemic from influenza is low.
it is in their interest to do so if possible.

Starting off with a base assumption of a low probability - around 10% - as modern medical methods of identifying and restricting outbreaks have improved since the last zoological flu pandemic.  However, new strains are coming to infect humans with increased reporting of human infections, mainly H7N9 in China.  WHO risk assessments for H7N9 are out of date, but monthly risk assessments of zoonotic flu strains remain as low.  However, viruses mutate (+5%), cases do go unreported (+5%), and there's always the chance of something new coming onto the scene (+2%), so bumping the probability up. Also, there are a fair few events in Asia over the next two years (+1%).  This pandemic alert is more likely to come from the WHO - if it comes at all.
Base rate is traceable, medical advances and response times have advanced. I'm at 5% for uncertainty's sake but this would be a surprise to me.

The definition of a flu pandemic, according to the World Health Organization's website; " (flu) pandemic occurs when a new influenza appears against which the human population has no immunity".  The general consensus among people who study influenza pandemics is 9 have occurred in the past 300 years.  If that number were accurate, that would mean there is a 3% chance of a flu pandemic.  It is doubtful the operating set of data are accurate.  The ability to keep track of millions of individual's illnesses throughout the world is only recently close to possible.  Also, declaring a flu pandemic would be adjacent to asking for money and the current US Administration is crudely cutting spending.  I predict the World Health Organization or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will not declare an influenza pandemic before 2019.  I put the odds at 8 to 1 because of possible new influenza measuring technology, constant changes of political climate and the threshold for declaration of a pandemic has no quantifiable threshold.
I am assuming this includes all types of flu, including bird flu?  If so, I would say there is a 20% likelihood that there will be a superbug(virus) in the next two years.

Influenza virus strands can mutate, but the preventions and ability to create vaccines decreases the likelihood of a virus reaching pandemic levels.  https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/12/1/05-1254_article
http://www.who.int/csr/don/17-january-2017-ah7n9-china/en/  WHO does not advise special screening at points of entry with regard to this event, nor does it currently recommend any travel or trade restrictions. As always, a diagnosis of infection with an avian influenza virus should be considered in individuals who develop severe acute respiratory symptoms while travelling in or soon after returning from an area where avian influenza is a concern. WHO encourages countries to continue strengthening influenza surveillance, including surveillance for severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and influenza-like illness (ILI) and to carefully review any unusual patterns, ensure reporting of human infections under the IHR (2005), and continue national health preparedness actions.
Flu pandemic is always on the horizon, it's always a toss of the coin if a mutation will occur that causes a pandemic, which is why I put the chance at slightly above fifty.

The base rate of flu pandemics seems to be at 3 per century, or roughly one every 33 years. With the last pandemic declared 8 years ago, assuming the probability increases linearly between two pandemics that occur every 33 years, would lead to 24% currently and 30% by 2019. 
I forecast higher probability because of intensified animal agriculture increasing the risk of animal to human transmission, increased air travel enabling quicker spread of emerging viruses. Factors that would reduce this probability would include improved early detection methods (did not research), increased awareness 
(which I judge to be true but not a factor that would reduce the risk significantly, in the end we are dealing with mutation and adaptation of the viruses, so awareness is going to slow down transmission, but not prevent emergence)

A severe pandemic is very rare, maybe twice in a century, and early treatment and containment is more possible nowadays. A mild pandemic (eg 2009) is more likely.

There've been about 5 pandemics in the last 100 years, so the there's about a 5% chance per year for a pandemic to begin. It's about 1.5 years until 2017, so that's 0.95 chance of a pandemic *not* occurring in 2018 multiplied by a 0.975 chance of it not occurring during the remainder of this year, and that's about 0.93. So, yeah, 7% chance is about right.

Unlikely before 2019. The two dominant disease cycles are ~30-36 year pandemic and ~11 solar/sunspot. While we're at the edge of a pandemic window (1981 + 30|36 ~ 2011-2017), the solar cycle peaked (max effect) in 2014, declining into ~2019. For those of VERY long term orientation, the next alignment of these cycles comes around 2080..

Overuse of antibiotics is increasing bacterial resistance, making a widespread outbreak more likely http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2017/bacteria-antibiotics-needed/en/. WHO has H5N1 currently in the Alert phase, one phase below pandemic http://www.who.int/influenza/preparedness/pandemic/h5n1phase/en/.
To avoid possible hysteria and overreaction, both organizations will be unwilling to declare a pandemic unless it is absolutely necessary. Many recent health threats have been regionally contained (Zika in South America, MERS in South Korea) and have been classified merely as an epidemic.

This is speculation at its' worse but my thought process runs along these lines.  As mentioned by Mr. Kumar each year farther from the previous pandemic can mean an increase in the odds that the next one will come around.  Second the world continues at a rapid pace to urbanize and since the last pandemic significantly greater actual numbers of humans as well as a % of humans are living in close contact with each other.  This will mean easier to spread quickly among the population.
Greater numbers of humans travel and to all areas of the world but again usually passing through major population area no matter what the final destination may be and therefore the spread can quickly become regional or worldwide which would create the pandemic label.
Migration is growing and uncontrolled movement of great numbers of people add to the risks of quickly spreading viruse.
Finally it generally the case that the very old are most at risk and we are now in a world with a never before seen number and % of the human population as older more vulnerable persons.  Therefore the influenza when it hits will find a significantly larger number of hosts than anytime previously.
I sincerely hope I am wrong but I see a lot of reason for us to be vigilant.

1) There have been about 9 Influenza pandemics during the last 300 years. It doesn't happen often. 2) There was one research group releasing a major warning about new strains: http://www.abc.net.au/radio/sydney/programs/mornings/flu/8421350 3) As Science magazine reported, that was a controversial study: http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2011/11/scientists-brace-media-storm-around-controversial-flu-studies 4) There are no announcements or news about the need for taking precautions on WHO or CDC. 5) Novel influenza A viruses with pandemic potential include Asian lineage avian influenza A (H5N1) and (H7N9) viruses but there are no news about recent infections. https://www.cdc.gov/flu/pandemic-resources/monitoring/viruses-concern.html We cannot neglect the risk (which is always there) but nothing seems to significantly increase that basic risk.
